content:
$$
\begin{array}{l} \mathbf {B} = \mu_ {0} (1 + \chi) \mathbf {H} \tag {5.14} \\ = \mu_ {0} \mu_ {\mathrm {r}} \mathbf {H} \\ = \mu \mathbf {H} \tag {5.15} \\ \end{array}
$$

where $\mu_{\mathrm{r}} = 1 + \chi$, is a dimensionless quantity called the relative magnetic permeability of the substance. It is the analog of the dielectric constant in electrostatics. The magnetic permeability of the substance is $\mu$ and it has the same dimensions and units as $\mu_0$:
summary: $$\begin{array}{l} \mathbf {B} = \mu_ {0} (1 + \chi) \mathbf {H} \\ = \mu_ {0} \mu_ {\mathrm {r}} \mathbf {H} \\ = \mu \mathbf {H} \\ \end{array}$$ where $\mu_{\mathrm{r}} = 1 + \chi$, is a dimensionless quantity called the relative magnetic permeability of the substance. It is the analog of the dielectric constant in electrostatics.
hypothetical_questions: What is the relationship between the magnetic field and the magnetic permeability of a material?
What is the significance of relative magnetic permeability in relation to the magnetic field?
How does the presence of free charges in a material affect magnetic permeability?
